section.title: File Filters
section.para: This dialog lists the available file filters. Filters used in the current project are displayed in bold. If you prefer not to use OmegaT to translate files of a certain type, you can turn off the corresponding filter by deactivating its check box. OmegaT will then omit the corresponding files when loading projects, and copy them unmodified to the target folder when creating target documents. Just tick the check box to start using the filter again. Click Restore Defaults to reset the file filters to their default settings. You can edit the file types and corresponding encoding covered by a filter by selecting it in the list and clicking the Edit... button.
The dialog allows you to enable or disable the following general options for all files:

listitem.para: Remove leading and trailing tags: uncheck this option to display all tags, including those at the beginning and end of the segment.

warning.para: Do not put any text before the first tag if all tags are displayed for Microsoft Open XML formats (.docx, .xlsx, etc.)—it is a technical tag that must always begin the segment.

listitem.para: Remove leading and trailing whitespace in non-segmented projects: By default, OmegaT removes any leading and trailing whitespace. In non-segmented projects, you can uncheck this option to retain that whitespace.
Preserve spaces for all tags: check this option if the source documents contain significant spaces that are used to control the layout and must not be ignored.

Ignore file context when identifying segments with alternate translations: By default, OmegaT uses the source file name as one of the elements that identify an alternative translation. If this option is checked, the source file name is not used, and alternative translations will apply in any file as long as the remaining identifying elements (previous/next segments, or a segment identifier, depending on the file format) matches.

section.title: Edit filter dialog
section.para: This dialog enables you to specify the source filename patterns for files to be processed by the filter, customize the filenames of translated files and select the encoding used for each file type when loading the source file and saving the translation. You can modify a file filter pattern either by typing directly in the fields or clicking the Edit... button. Click the Add... button to add a new file filter pattern. The same dialog is used to adding and edit patterns. It includes a special target filename pattern editor that lets you customize how output files are named.

section.title: Source filename pattern
section.para: OmegaT attempts to select a filter based on the extension of the file loaded from the project’s source folder. More precisely, it attempts to match the source filename patterns in each filter against the filename. For example, the pattern *.xhtml matches any file with the .xhtml extension. If an appropriate filter is found, the file is assigned to it for processing. For example, by default, the XHTML filter is used to process files with the .xhtml extension. You can change or add filename patterns to specify what files are handled by an individual filter. Source filename patterns use wild card characters similar to those used in Searches. The “*” character matches zero or more characters, while the “?” character matches exactly one character. All other characters are interpreted as is. For example, if you want to have the text filter handle readme files (readme, read.me, or readme.txt) you can use the pattern read*.

section.title: Source and translated file encoding
section.para: A limited number of file formats specify a mandatory encoding. For other file formats, the encoding you specify for the extension that matches their name will be used. For example, .txt files will be loaded using the default encoding of your operating system if no other encoding is specified. You can change the source encoding for each different source filename pattern. Target files can also be written using any encoding. By default, the encoding of the translated file is the same as that of the source file. The source and target encoding fields use drop-down menus listing all supported encodings. Selecting the <auto> option leaves the choice of encoding to OmegaT, based on the following criteria.

listitem.para: OmegaT uses the encoding declaration in the source file, if present, to identify the encoding (HTML- or XML-based files).
OmegaT is instructed to use a mandatory encoding for certain file formats (Java properties, for example).
OmegaT uses the default encoding of the operating system for text files.

section.title: Translated filename
section.para: You may want to rename the files you translate automatically, by adding a language code after the file name, for example. The target filename pattern uses a special syntax. The easiest way to modify this field is to click the Edit... button and use the Edit Pattern dialog. You can also modify the name directly in the target filename pattern field of the file filters dialog. If you want to revert to the default filter configuration after making changes, click the Restore Defaults button. Your changes only take effect after you click the OK button to close the Edit Filter dialog. The Edit Pattern dialog offers various options. A non-exhaustive list is presented below.

listitem.para: ${filename}—The default pattern. It represents the complete filename of the source file, including the extension. Using this pattern assigns the translated file the exact same name as the source file.
${nameOnly}— Inserts just the name of the source file, without the extension.
${extension} —Inserts the original file extension.
${targetLocale}—Inserts the target locale code (in “xx_YY” format).
${targetLanguage}—Inserts the target language and country code together (in “xx-YY” format).
${targetLanguageCode}—Inserts only the target language code (“xx”).
${targetCountryCode}—Inserts only the target country code (“YY”).
${timestamp-????}—Inserts the system date and time when the file is created. Various date and time patterns are available.
See the Oracle documentation for examples of the SimpleDateFormat patterns.
${system-os-name}—Inserts the name of operating system used to create the file.
${system-user-name}—Inserts the user’s login name.
${system-host-name}—Inserts the host name assigned to the system.
${file-source-encoding}—Inserts the encoding of the source file.
${file-target-encoding}—Inserts the encoding of the target file.
${targetLocaleLCID}—Inserts the Microsoft target locale.

section.para: Additional variants are available for the ${nameOnly} and ${Extension} variables. If the file name is ambiguous, variables of the form ${name only-extension number} and ${extension-extension number} can be used. For a source file named Document.xx.docx, using the variable variants below will produce the following results:

listitem.para: <${nameOnly-0}: Document
${nameOnly-1}: Document.xx
${nameOnly-2}: Document.xx.docx
${extension-0}: docx
${extension-1}: xx.docx
${extension-2}: Document.xx.docx

section.title: Segmentation Setup
section.para: Translation memory tools work with textual units called segments. OmegaT has two ways to segment a text: paragraph segmentation, and sentence segmentation (also referred to as “rule-based segmentation”). Select the type of segmentation by going to Project Properties... from the main menu and ticking or unticking the applicable check box. Paragraph segmentation is advantageous in certain cases, such as highly creative or stylistic translations in which the translator prefers to rearrange entire sentences. For the majority of projects, however, sentence segmentation is preferred as since it delivers better matches from previous translations. If sentence segmentation is used, you can select OptionsSegmentation...from the main menu to define segmentation rules.

Dependable segmentation rules are already available for many languages, so you are unlikely to have to write your own segmentation rules. However, this function can be very useful in special cases, where you can increase your productivity by fine-tuning the segmentation rules to the text to translate.

warning.para: Making changes to the segmentation options will segment the text differently, and may require you to start translating from scratch. At the same time any previously valid segments in the project translation memory will turn into orphan segments. If you change the segmentation options when a project is open, you will have to reload it for the changes to take effect.

section.para: OmegaT divides the text two translate in two steps:

listitem.para: OmegaT first parses the text for structure-level segmentation. This process relies only on the structure of the source file to produce segments.

For example, text files may be segmented on line breaks, empty lines, or not at all. Files containing formatting (ODF, HTML, or other documents) are divided at block-level (paragraph) tags. Translatable object attributes in XHTML or HTML files can be extracted as separate segments.
After dividing the source file into structural units, OmegaT further divides the blocks into segments.

section.title: Segmentation rules
section.para: You can visualize segmentation as the process of moving the cursor along the text, on character at a time. Each time the cursor moves to the next character, rules consisting of a Before and After pattern, are checked, in order, for a match with the Before pattern on the left and the corresponding After pattern on the right. The first matching rule is applied, either by creating a new segment break at the current cursor position (for a break rule), or by moving the cursor to the next position without inserting a segment break (for an exception rule).
The two types of rules behave as follows:

listitem.para: Separates the source text into segments. For example, “Did it make sense? I was not sure.” should be split into two segments. This requires a break rule for the “?” character when it is followed by spaces and a capitalized word. To define a rule as a break rule, tick the Break/Exception check box.

Specify text combinations that should not be separated. In spite of the period, the expression "Mrs. Dalloway " should not be split in two segments, so an exception rule is necessary for Mrs (as well as Mr, Dr, prof, etc.), followed by a period. To define an exception rule, leave the Break/Exception check box unticked.

section.para: The predefined break rules should be sufficient for most European languages and Japanese. In view of the flexibility provided by the rules, however, you may consider defining more exception rules for your source language to obtain more meaningful and coherent segments.

section.title: Rule priority
section.para: All segmentation rule sets for a matching language pattern are active and are applied in order of priority. Therefore, rules for specific language should be higher than default ones. For example, the rules for Canadian French (FR-CA) should be set higher than those for French (FR.*), which should themselves be higher than the Default (.*) set. Thus, when translating from Canadian French the rules for Canadian French—if any—will apply first, followed by the rules for French and lastly, by the Default rules.

section.title: Creating a new rule
section.para: Major changes to the segmentation rules should be generally avoided, especially after completing a first draft, but minor changes, such as the addition of a recognized abbreviation, can be advantageous.
Simply click on the desired set of rules in the table in the upper part of the dialog to edit or expand it. The rules for that set will appear in the bottom part of the dialog.

If you want to create an empty set of rules for a new language pattern click the Add button in the upper half of the dialog. An empty line will appear at the bottom of the table in the upper part of the dialog (you may have to scroll down to see it). Change the name of the rule set and the language pattern to the desired language and corresponding code. The syntax of the language pattern conforms to regular expression syntax. If your set of rules handles a language-country pair, we advise you to move it to the top using the Move Up button.

Add the Before and After patterns. We recommend using tools that allow you to see their effect directly to check their syntax and applicability. See Regular expressions. The existing rules always provide a good starting point.

section.para: Click on Glossary to configure the Auto-completer glossary view.

section.title: Spellchecker
section.para: OmegaT has a built-in spellchecker based on the spellchecking software used in Apache OpenOffice, LibreOffice, Firefox and Thunderbird. It is consequently able to use the huge range of free spelling dictionaries available for these applications.

listitem.para: Select the location of the language checker.
Using a different language checker on your local machine than the one supplied with OmegaT allows you to customize the verification rules.
Check or uncheck the rules depending on whether they are relevant to the type of text you are translating.

section.title: Editor

listitem.para: You can have the source text inserted automatically into the editing field. This is useful for texts containing many trademarks or other proper nouns that must be left unchanged.

OmegaT leaves the editing field blank. This option allows you to enter the translation without the need to remove the source text, thus saving you two keystrokes (CA and Del). Empty translations are now allowed. They are displayed as <EMPTY> in the Editor. To create one, right-click in a segment, and select Set empty translation. The entry Remove translation in the same context menu allows you to delete the existing translation of the current segment. You achieve the same effect by clearing the target segment and pressing Enter.

OmegaT inserts the translation of the string most similar to the current source, if it exceeds the similarity threshold you set in this dialog. The prefix (empty by default) can be used to identify translations inserted as fuzzy matches. If you add a prefix (for instance [fuzzy]), you can easily track down those translations later to make sure they are correct.

section.para: The remaining options are described below.

varlistentry.term: Attempt to convert numbers when inserting a fuzzy match

listitem.para: If this option is checked, OmegaT attempts to convert the numbers in the fuzzy matches according to the source contents when a fuzzy match is inserted either manually or automatically. There are a number of restrictions:
The source segment and the fuzzy matches must contain the same list of numbers.
The numbers must be exactly the same between the source and the target matches.
Only integers and simple floats (using the period as a decimal character, e.g., 5.4, but not 5,4 or 54E-01) are considered.

varlistentry.term: Allow translation to be equal to source

listitem.para: The documents to translate may contain trademarks, names or other proper nouns that will remain the same in the translated versions. There are two strategies to handle segments containing only such unchanging text.

You can decide not to translate such segments at all. OmegaT will then report these segments as not translated. This is the default approach. The alternative is to enter a translation that is identical to the source text. OmegaT can be set to recognize such entries by selecting this option.

varlistentry.term: Export the segment to text files

listitem.para: The text export function exports data from within the current OmegaT project to plain text files. The data is exported when the segment is opened. The files appear in the script subfolder of the OmegaT user files folder, and include:
The content of the segment source text (source.txt).
The content of the segment target text (target.txt).
The text that had been highlighted by the user before pressing CSc or clicking EditExport Selection is selected (selection.txt).

The content of the files is overwritten either when a new segment is opened (source.txt and target.txt) or when a new selection is exported (selection.txt). The files are unformatted plain text files. The whole process can be steered and controlled via Tck/Tcl-based scripting. See Using the OmegaT text export function for specifics, examples and suggestions.

varlistentry.term: Go To Next Untranslated Segment stops where there is at least one alternative translation

listitem.para: Ticking this check box will cause the Go To Next Untranslated Segment command to stop at each segment with more than one possible translation, irrespective of whether it has already been translated. This allows you to make sure there are no mistranslations.

Leave this option unchecked to prevent any corruption of the tags (such as a partial deletion) during editing. You can still remove a complete tag with CBackspace/Delete, or by selecting it (using the mouse or CSLeft/Right key combination), and deleting it (Delete or Cx).

listitem.para: Check this option to be warned about differences between source and target segments tags each time you leave a segment.

Check this option to record the fact that a segment has been auto-populated in the project_save.tmx file. This makes it possible to display those segments in a specific color in the Editor (if the "Mark Auto-Populated Segments" option in the View menu is checked).

listitem.para: You can also use regular expressions to define custom tags.
For example, you can enter \d+ into the field to treat all numbers as tags, enabling you to check that numbers have not been accidentally changed in the translation.
Similarly, you can use <.*?> to make sure that HTML (or similar) tags entered into the source text are preserved without modification in the translation.
You can also combine both of the above custom tags into a single expression: (<.*?>)|(\d+).

section.title: Proxy Login
section.para: If OmegaT needs to use an authenticated proxy server to access the Internet, enter the details provided by the proxy administrator here.

section.title: Secure store
section.para: This option lets you define or reset the master password used to protect login details and access keys for machine translation services. Always make a backup of that information before creating a new password, because they will all be deleted and have to be re-entered.

section.title: Plugins
section.para: This option shows a list of available plugins. They are installed either in the plugins folder under the OmegaT installation folder, or in the platform-specific OmegaT .
Additional plugins can be found on the OmegaT development site site.

section.title: Updates
section.para: Use this option to choose whether to be automatically notified of updates to OmegaT.
